page.title: 02Landscape south of Buriton
page.content: This is an area of chalk upland reaching almost 200 metres, with a north facing escarpment that is mainly wooded with mature deciduous trees. One stream flows northwards, rising above the Wooliffe pond and flowing into the River Rother. Southwards is a dip slope which is desected by several dry valleys which minor roads run through. This area was originally chalk turf but it is now woodland planted by the Forestry Commission. This forest is interspersed with arable fields of mainly cereal crops and some grazing land. The old lime workings on the scarp slope are now wooded and little shows of the excavations. Southwards (particularly from the Ditcham area) is a splendid panorama, with distant views of the Solent & Isle of Wight. Most of the 20 dwellings are built of malm & flint.
